text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with sticky buns that's right the
first recipe i ever made for my family
after coming home after my first
semester at culinary school was sticky
buns and to be honest i don't remember
how they came out although I do remember
everyone enjoying them or at least
pretending to and ever since then
they've had a special place in my heart
which is why it's so astounding I've
never done a video for these but hey at
least that gave me time to perfect the
recipe and perfect I did so with that
let's go hang get started with our dough
which will begin with some very warm
water as well as some very warm milk
over which we will sprinkle one package
of dry active yeast and what we like to
do is wait about ten minutes to see if
it's active which it always is as
indicated by those little bubbles around
the edge and then to this we will add
some white sugar 1 large bead neg and a
whole bunch of melted butter and I will
go ahead and take a whisk and give this
a quick mix before finishing up with our
flour insults except when I want to do
that something very very rare occurred
right it only happens once every like
200 videos which is I thought the camera
was on but I must have double clicked it
and it was really off so you don't get
to see me add it in but so you don't
miss anything let me show you how it
looked all right I added the flour with
this bowl and then I used a small
ramekin to add the salt and that's it
now that you're all caught up we can
grab our dough hook and give this a few
stirs for no apparent reason
before we head to the mixer to create
our dough and as usual I did not add all
the flour in okay I like to add in about
75% of it and then give that a mix and
then once the mixture looks like this
which is clearly way too loose we can go
ahead and add some more in and we'll
continue doing that till all the flowers
in or we've added enough to make this
come together and when I say come
together I don't mean into a tight ball
of dough I'm talking just barely barely
come together to form a very very
extremely soft dough at which point we
will let this knead for about five
minutes after which it should look a
little something like this and if you're
thinking that looks like it's too loose
to work with well this sorta is but if
you want the world's best sticky buns
this is what we have to deal with and as
you'll see it's going to be fine
so we'll go ahead and pull that off the
mixer and scrape down our hook and then
let me go ahead and give this a few
turns with the spatula so you can get a
good idea what the texture should look
like and even though this is very loose
and very sticky as you can see we built
up enough gluten where this really does
kind of hold together and then what
we're supposed to do at this point is
transfer this into a nice clean Bowl
that we rubbed lightly with oil but you
know what I'm gonna skip that step and
just let it rise in this bowl it's gonna
be fine and then all we need to do is
cover this and let it rise in a warm
spot for about an hour or so or until it
doubles in size and while we're waiting
we will move on to make our sticky nut
topping which is gonna start with some
light brown sugar some regular white
sugar a small but very important touch
of salt as well as a whole bunch of
melted butter and then a few tablespoons
of water and then once all that's in
there we'll go ahead and give this a
very thorough mixing with a spatula or
maybe a whisk would work even better but
the point is go ahead and mix that until
smooth and then once that's been
accomplished we'll go ahead and transfer
that into a very well buttered metal
baking pan and yes that is my detroit
pizza pan but as long as it's metal and
about 13 by 9 it will work and you can
and I have done this in a glass pan but
if you can try to use metal because it
does seem to work a little better and
then what we'll do once we have that
spread out evenly it sprinkle over a
very generous cup of chopped pecans and
for whatever reason if you're not into
pecans you could use walnuts which are
also very nice in this so use what you
want I mean you guys are after all the
job of the huts of your sticky nuts but
personally I think the sweeter and
richer pecan works the best here and
that's it once those have been evenly
applied we will simply set that aside
until needed and we'll move on to mix up
the last component which is simply a
cinnamon spice brown sugar that we'll
use to spread over our dough before we
roll it up so we'll go ahead and give
that a good mix and we'll set that aside
and then go check our dough which after
about an hour or so should look a little
something like this
and a lot of times we would punch it
down at this point just for fun but
don't even bother because what we're
gonna do with very very well floured
fingers is go ahead and transfer this
onto a lightly floured surface and then
somehow someway using just enough flour
so it doesn't stick to our hands
we're gonna press it and stretch it out
into a big rectangle and yes it will and
is sticking to the table which is fine
okay because this dough is so elastic
and has so much butter in it even though
it will kind of stick to the counter as
you'll see when we start rolling this it
should release and come off fairly
cleanly and if it doesn't you can blame
me and if you want to try to use a
roller go ahead but I think a couple
flat floured hands are the best tools
and by using your hands even though we
are flattening this out fairly thin
we're not pressing out all the tiny
bubbles like a rolling pin might and
then what we'll do once that is into a
rectangle about I don't know let's say
18 by 15 something like that we'll go
ahead and sprinkle over our cinnamon
brown sugar mixture and it's fine to go
all the way to the ends but along the
two longer edges we should probably
leave about an inch to two inches unsure
so the dough seals when we roll it up
and then once that's been applied we'll
give it a light pressing with our hands
just to sort of make sure it's all
evenly distributed and press down a
little bit into the dough at which point
we can start rolling this up and because
this dough is so sticky and soft this
will be the most challenging part of the
recipe and by challenging I mean fun and
exciting and as I mentioned earlier
because of the elasticity and high fat
content in the dough it really should
come out fairly easily and pretty clean
but where that stickiness will cause
issues is with your fingertips alright
so make sure you keep those floured as
necessary so that somehow some way you
can roll this up into a nice fairly even
cylinder and then what we'll do once
that is totally tubular and we've given
that one last shaping with our hands to
make sure it's as uniform as possible
we'll take the edge of a knife and score
this into twelve equal portions but we
are just making marks we are not going
to cut this with a knife right this
dough is so soft it would be really
really hard to cover the knife which is
why what we'll do is take a piece of
string and slide it underneath until it
reaches the appropriate spot and then
we'll simply cross the ends and pull in
opposite directions which as you can see
will do a beautiful job cutting this
dough fairly neatly and I'm just using
regular kitchen string here but some
unflavored dental floss will also work
and maybe even better and that's it once
cut we'll go ahead and transfer those
into our pan making three rows of four
buns each
and by the way when you place these in
if one side has a little thicker dough
than the other place the dough your side
up okay if you can't tell the difference
it doesn't matter and what's gonna
happen here is once these are baked
we're actually gonna flip the pan over
so that our sticky nut mixture ends up
being on the top and in the business we
call this topping from the bottom so
whatever you think the best-looking side
is place that down against the nuts and
then before we can bake these what we're
gonna do is temp these loosely with foil
and let them rise for about 45 minutes
to an hour or until they almost double
in size sure you could use plastic wrap
if you want but if we use the foil we
can also use that later in the oven if
they're getting too Brown but anyway the
point is cover those and let them rise
for about an hour or until they look
like this and that's it once these have
been proofed as we call it they are
ready to transfer into the center of a
375 degree oven for about 35 minutes or
so or until they reach an internal temp
of 200 degrees and as I mentioned near
the end of the baking time if they look
like they're getting too Brown go ahead
and pop that foil on which I did for the
last five minutes but anyway this is
what mine looked like after 35 minutes
which are beautiful as is but they're
gonna get even more so and then what
we'll do at this point is let those sit
down a rack for exactly five minutes all
right no more and no less because if you
flip these too soon and it's too loose
things might slide out and get messy but
if you wait too long and the sugar
hardens they might not come out at all
so we'll leave them on that rack exactly
five minutes at which point we will very
carefully but with extreme confidence
flip these over onto a platter revealing
one of the greatest sights in all the
culinary world I mean come on look at
that and then what we'll do after our
successful dismount is take a spoon and
transfer any of those sticky nuts that
were left in the pan back on top of our
buns into whatever spot we can see some
are missing and that's it all we need to
do at this point is let them cool down a
little
ideally until they're just warm at which
point we can go in for a taste and even
though this looks like one giant sticky
bun they will generally separate fairly
easily as you can see and as you bite
into this thing you will finally
understand why we wanted that dough so
soft and so sticky because the texture
of these is going to be so impossibly
light and airy but still
just that perfect amount of slight
chewiness and had we added more flour
into the dough to make it easier to work
with we would not be experiencing nearly
the same button okay it's definitely
been my experience with baking that the
harder our dough is to work with the
better it comes out which is sort of the
same thing with people sometimes and of
course the contrast between that
beautifully tender Airy dough and that
sweet crunchy sticky topping is just
otherworldly and by the way that corner
piece I tore off first I think was one
of the dough ear pieces and probably was
an end piece so here for the sake of
science I played it up another one so I
could cut it in half and show you how if
properly rolled you're gonna see those
beautiful layers of dough and cinnamon
sugar so not to Pat myself on the back
but this really did come out perfectly
in every way and having said that even
imperfect sticky buns are still amazing
so don't be discouraged if you have a
few issues the first time you try this
like I'm sure I did back in 1981 but
whether these come out perfectly or your
family just tells you they did I really
do hope you give these a try soon so
please follow the links below for the
ingredient amounts a principle written
recipe and much more info as usual and
as always enjoy
[Music]
you
you
